results.title: Tomb of the lost king
results.creator_credit: Roy Davies and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Chronicle”.
With the discovery in 1977 of Royal Tombs in the Greek village of Vergina, Greek archaeologist Manolis Andronikos uncovered the greatest prize left in Greek archaeology - the tomb of Philip II of Macedon. Shows the magnificent objects found inside the tomb including a mural believed to be the work of the ancient artist Nico Marco and examines the work and theories of the archaeologist. Narrated by Andrew Faulds.

results.title: The Incas
results.creator_credit: Anna Benson Gyles and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Chronicle”.
Little is known about the Inca empire, which stretched over 2,000 miles from Ecuador to Chile, during the 15th and 16th centuries. However archaeologists are busy digging behind the myths and legends surrounding the Incas and are learning more about how they ran their enormous empire so successfully. Narrated by Ian Holm.

results.title: The Pacific century
results.creator_credit: Christopher Spencer, BBC and Oxford Film and Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Chris Patten’s east and west”.
Final part of the three part documentary series “Chris Patten’s East and West” written and presented by the former British governor of Hong Kong, Chris Patten. In this episode Patten continues his discussion on the Asian economic miracle questioning the popular belief that the new millenium will belong to the Pacific Rim. He briefly talks about Thailand, from the days of its feudal society to its now modern industrial state which is facing an economic crisis following a crash in the “building boom” of the 1990s. More in depth coverage however, is given to Singapore and Japan - historical, economical and political - pointing out the differences in culture and traditions of both nations and the reasons behind their successes and failures in the world of economics. He points out Singapore’s reliance on its efficient, well educated and willing workforce who forego their individual rights and freedoms for the common good of the State and Japan’s tradition of loyalty to the company and a “job for life” being put under pressure as the younger generation demand freedom and choice in their careers and workplace culture. The program contains several interviews with various leaders and company personnel including the former Prime Minister of Singapore, Lee Kwan Yew, along with Chris Patten’s personal commentary and opinions. The series is well presented, informative and interesting from a socio-economic point of view - Chris Patten provides the human touch. Contains b&w archival footage and stills.

results.title: Chris Patten's east and west
results.creator_credit: Peter Minns, BBC and Oxford Film and Television
results.brief_description: Former Governor of Hong Kong, Chris Patten provides a politico-economic tour of some countries affected by the Asian economic crisis, speaking with many of the leading economists and politicians involved. He assesses the repercussions of changing attitudes towards Asia, shows how the collapse of the economies of South East Asia have effected ordinary people, and discusses Asian culture and values that have build up over time.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Peter Minns, BBC and Oxford Film and Television

results.title: Tiger talk
results.creator_credit: Jonathan Dent, Kim Jungeun, BBC and Oxford Film and Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Chris Patten’s east and west”.
Second of the three part documentary series “Chris Patten’s East and West” written and presented by the former British governor of Hong Kong, Chris Patten. In this episode the focus is on the economic crisis which spread across Asia during the late 1990s and the reasons behind the death of the so-called “Asian tigers”. Chris Patten points out once again the often crucial missing link with economical reform is political reform. Both Indonesia and South Korea, “Asian tigers” for several decades were ruled by authoritarian Presidents and in Indonesia’s case, the dictator President Suharto and his corrupt family. By presenting a detailed historical background on South Korea and a briefer outlook on Indonesia, Patten attempts to provide an insight and understanding on Asian economics, the relationship between government and private industry, between free trade and the industrial revolution in Asia, political oppression and student uprisings, company debts and the International Monetary Fund and finally the streamlining of the labor market through redundancies and restructure. Included in the program are interviews with B.J. Habibie (President, Republic of Indonesia 1998), Milton Kim (Chairman, Ssangyong Investment & Securities), and Kim Dae Jung (South Korean Opposition Leader 1961-1997). Contains b&w archival footage and stills.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jonathan Dent, Kim Jungeun, BBC and Oxford Film and Television

results.title: Barbarian diplomacy
results.creator_credit: Peter Minns, BBC and Oxford Film and Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Chris Patten’s east and west”.
First of the three part documentary series “Chris Patten’s East and West” written and presented by the former British governor of Hong Kong, Chris Patten. In this episode Patten focuses on China - socially, economically and politically - from its past history to the China of the 90s. He more specifically deals with human rights and economic reform emphasising his strong belief that it is important “to keep trade and human rights separate” and that “economical reform requires political reform”. The program covers President Nixon’s visit and his meeting with Mao Tse-tung in 1972; the US/China alliance and lifting of trade restrictions; the rise of Deng Xaioping and the reform movement following Mao’s death; the Tiananmen Square massacre of 1989; international and trade relations at the expense of human rights recognition; President Clinton’s visit in 1998. Also briefly looks at human rights issues in Burma through an interview with the Burmese Opposition Leader, Aung San Suu Kyi who has been politically isolated under house arrest for over 9 years, followed by a comparison to Taiwan, a mainly Chinese capitalist society, democratic and free and a thorn in China’s side. Includes interviews with Henry Kissinger (US National Security Adviser 1969-75), Paul Wolfowitz (US Assistant Secretary of State, Asia 1982-86), Winston Lord (US Foreign Policy Adviser 1970-73) and Sir Alan Donald (British Ambassador, Beijing 1988-91) among others. Contains b&w archival footage and stills.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Peter Minns, BBC and Oxford Film and Television
